quiz.title: Day 1: FHIR Data Ingestion
quiz.description: Test your understanding of FHIR data ingestion concepts

questions.stem: When uploading patient data to a FHIR server, which Bundle type should you use?
questions.explanation: Transaction bundles are used when creating or updating resources on a FHIR server. They ensure atomic operations - either all resources are processed successfully, or none are.

questions.stem: What's the difference between a FHIR resource 'id' and an 'identifier'?

choices.label: ID is server-assigned and unique per server; identifier is business-assigned and globally meaningful
ID is for humans; identifier is for computers
Identifiers are only used in bundles

questions.explanation: Resource IDs are assigned by the FHIR server and only unique within that server. Identifiers are business identifiers like SSN, MRN, or other meaningful codes that have significance across systems.

questions.stem: In a FHIR Bundle, how do you reference a Patient from an Observation that doesn't have a server ID yet?
questions.explanation: In transaction bundles, use temporary UUIDs (like 'urn:uuid:12345') to reference resources that don't have server IDs yet. The server will resolve these references during processing.

questions.stem: Why do we use Synthea data in this bootcamp instead of real patient data?

choices.label: Real PHI should never be uploaded to public test servers
Synthea data is easier to work with
Public servers don't accept real data

questions.explanation: Using real protected health information (PHI) on public test servers violates HIPAA and other privacy regulations. Always use synthetic or de-identified data for learning and testing.

questions.stem: When exporting FHIR resources to CSV for analytics, what's the main challenge?

choices.label: FHIR resources are hierarchical/nested, CSV is flat

questions.explanation: FHIR resources have complex nested structures (arrays, objects within objects), while CSV is a flat format. You need to flatten or denormalize the data structure.

questions.stem: After uploading a Bundle with 10 Patient resources and 25 Observation resources, your analytics show 35 total resources. What does this indicate?
questions.explanation: 35 total resources (10 Patients + 25 Observations) indicates a successful upload where all resources in the bundle were processed correctly.

questions.stem: What FHIR version are we using in this bootcamp?
questions.explanation: This bootcamp uses FHIR R4, which is the current widely-adopted standard. R4 is stable and supported by most healthcare systems.

questions.stem: Before uploading a Bundle to a FHIR server, what should you always check first?
questions.explanation: The CapabilityStatement tells you which resource types the server supports, what operations are allowed, and what FHIR version it uses. Always check this first.
